headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Henningsen, Victor W.
summary: HENNINGSEN--Victor W. , Jr, Sound Shore Health System mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Victor W. Henningsen, Jr. Together with his family, Vic was a steadfast supporter of Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester and a devoted member of the Board of Governors, serving from 1985 to the present. During this time he was Chairman of the Board from 1991-1994. His commitment to providing our community with the highest level of health care services by furthering the mission of the Medical Center will be forever remembered at Sound Shore. We will miss his guidance and support. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife Mayde and their children and grandchildren. Mauro C. Romita, Chairman John R. Spicer, President and CEO $(6$)HENNINGSEN--Victor William Jr., of Pelham Manor, NY, died March 26, 2007. Born May 19, 1924, he was a lifelong resident of the town of Pelham. He leaves his beloved wife of 58 years, Mayde, his children and their spouses: Vic and Susan, of Andover, MA; Kit and Caroline, of Stony Creek, CT; Mary and Chris, of Pelham Manor; Tim and Anne, of Wexford, PA; and eight grandchildren. Also survived by his brother, John T. Henningsen, of Rye, and sister, Ann H. Kneisel, of Boston, MA. Educated at Phillips Academy, the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, and Yale. During World War II he served in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and Indian Ocean war zones as a midshipman, third and second mate in the merchant navy, finishing as Lt. (JG) USNR. He spent his entire professional career with the family firm, Henningsen Foods Inc., founded by his grandfather in 1889. Starting as an office boy and plant worker, he retired as President and CEO in 1993 and served as Chairman Emeritus until his death. He was an international leader in the poultry and egg industry as a founder and chairman of the Egg Products Association, a trustee of the Nutrition Foundation and a longtime director of the Institute of American Poultry. He received many industry honors and awards. Profoundly committed to education, he was an active volunteer for Andover, the USMMA, Yale, and Sweet Briar College, where he was past president of the Board of Trustees. A longtime trustee of the Chapel of St. Thomas More at Yale, he was also past president of the Yale Club of NYC and of the American Friends of the Bermuda Maritime Museum. He devoted much time and energy to his native town, particularly the village of Pelham Manor, serving over the years as chair of the Pelham Community Chest, member of the village Planning Board, trustee and mayor of the village of Pelham Manor, cochairman of the Friends of the Pelham Town Library, and chairman of the board of the Sound Shore Medical Center. At his death he was still active in efforts to bridge political divisions and bring people together in service to the community he loved. Memorial Mass, 11 AM, Saturday, March 31, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Fowler Ave, Pelham Manor, NY. Interment private. Contributions in his memory to the Friends of the Pelham Town Library, 530 Colonial Avenue, Pelham, NY, 10803; and the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY, 10801.

headline: On the Way Out But Feeling O.K.
summary: What's one year and 335 days between brothers? At Alcoa, where Ricardo E. Belda was a senior executive until last fall, it is nothing.

headline: Mission: Acquirable? Breaking The Code
summary: THE merger boom has created a subplot perfect for a spy thriller: a proliferation of code names that executives and investment bankers use to disguise the parties in a potential deal. Often inspired by Greek gods, sports figures or city names, the code names turn up in early presentations in place of actual company names, which, at least in theory, are supposed to stay secret until an agreement is announced. A common approach is to substitute a word with the same first letter of each company, although deal makers sometimes get more fanciful.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: SWEATSHOP CRACKDOWN -- China is planning to adopt a new law that seeks to crack down on sweatshops and protect workers' rights by giving labor unions real power for the first time since Bejing introduced market forces in the late 1970's. [Page A1.] LIFE AFTER MARTHA -- Life for Peter E. Bacanovic, the former stockbroker convicted on two charges of lying to investigators in the ImClone insider-trading case that also landed Martha Stewart in jail, has been a slow trudge through the slough of a legal and regulatory despond. Mr. Bacanovic, above, fired from his job at Merrill Lynch and banned from the securities industry, is now struggling to find a permanent job and restore some shine to his tattered health and psyche. [C1.] HARD SELL FOR M.B.A. STUDENTS -- Some companies, trying to attract M.B.A. students, are offering bonuses that decline in value or disappear unless the student accepts the job by a certain date. [C1.] INFLATION THREAT SAID TO LOWER -- Maybe the sputtering housing market is not that big of a drag on the economy after all. Falling gas prices are leaving Americans with more money to spend, and inflation has become less of a threat in recent weeks, according to a report released by the Federal Reserve. [C1.] TRASH A CHALLENGE IN IRAQ -- In Baghdad, a city where a bomb could be lurking beneath any heap of refuse, garbage collection, an occupation that pays a few dollars a day, has become one of the deadliest. [A8.] RESIGNATIONS OVER BACKDATING -- The Boston Communications Group, a provider of prepaid wireless services, said it was replacing its three top executives and that it would restate earnings after discovering backdated stock options. [C4.] THE COMMERCIAL IS THE MESSAGE -- Fireman's Fund is joining a lengthening list of marketers branching out beyond TV commercials into sponsoring programs. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] BUSH PLEDGE ON BIO-FUELS -- At a conference to promote bio-fuels, President Bush suggested that the push to wean America from its oil addiction would be a priority of the last two years of his presidency. [C3.] DEAL ON REAL ESTATE LISTINGS -- The Federal Trade Commission said that five regional real estate listing services had agreed to treat listings from discount brokers no differently than those from full-service agents. [C3.] DELTA CHIEF TO RETIRE -- The chief executive of Delta Air Lines, Gerald Grinstein, said he planned to retire after the airline emerged from bankruptcy protection, but he declined to say who would succeed him. [C4.] STRONG QUARTER FOR COSTCO -- The Costco Wholesale Corporation said that its fourth-quarter profit edged up less than a percentage point as its revenue climbed 19 percent and that operating results were unexpectedly strong late in the quarter. [C4.] I.B.M. MOVES OPERATION TO CHINA -- I.B.M. has moved its global procurement headquarters to southern China from the suburbs of New York City to ''capitalize on emerging market opportunities.'' [C4.] RULING AGAINST WAL-MART -- Wal-Mart Stores forced employees to work through rest breaks and to put in extra hours without pay, violating Pennsylvania labor laws, a state jury found. [C6.] CHINA PROMOTES UNIONS -- Workers have set up unions at all 66 Wal-Mart outlets in China, beginning what a Chinese union official described as a wider campaign aimed at other foreign companies. [C6.] SAFEWAY MEETS ESTIMATES -- Safeway, the grocer, posted a 42 percent rise in quarterly profit, matching expectations, but its shares fell as the growth failed to surpass forecasts. [C6.] AIRBUS ON THE DEFENSIVE -- With Airbus in the deepest crisis of its 36-year history, its corporate parent, the European Aerospace Defense and Space Company, is reshuffling its management in an attempt to correct quality problems that have delayed delivery of the Airbus A380 superjumbo jet. [C1.] H.P. NAMES GENERAL COUNSEL -- Hewlett-Packard said it had named Jon Hoak, former general counsel for NCR, as its vice president and chief ethics and compliance officer, succeeding Kevin T. Hunsaker, who was ousted after his involvement in a boardroom spying inquiry was disclosed last month. [C6.] HALT TO ENERGY ACQUISITION -- Energy Partners has called off its plan to acquire the Stone Energy Corporation and said it may offer itself for sale. Shares of both companies rose on the news. [C7.] DOW HITS ANOTHER RECORD -- The Dow Jones industrial average broke through 11,900 to close at a another record high, aided by optimism over the health of corporate earnings. [C9.] HOMESTORE OFFICIAL SENTENCED -- Stuart Wolff, former chief executive of Homestore Inc., an online home-listings business, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for directing a $67 million fraud at the company. [C9.]

headline: HIDING THE AFFAIR, NOT FRAUD
summary: It was a brazen defense, and in the end the jury didn't buy it. Andrew N. Yao, who was chief executive of the former Student Finance Corporation, claimed that he did not commit fraud when he lied in federal bankruptcy court about wiring $669,000 to his mistress at the time, a former Playboy Playmate of the Month. Though he initially said the money was for maintaining his private jets, he later acknowledged that it was for his girlfriend. But he said he wasn't trying to deceive his company's creditors or the court. He said he was lying only so that his family wouldn't find out about the affair.

headline: Homegrown News
summary: THE notion of a 24-hour cable news channel that trains its cameras exclusively on Westchester County and the surrounding Hudson Valley probably conjures up images of live reports on the cheerleading squad at a New Rochelle high school or news-you-can-use from the latest health forum at a county senior center. In fact, News 12 Westchester, a cable news station that reaches more than 400,000 households from its headquarters high on a hill in Yonkers, where it shares a parking lot with a Bennigan's restaurant, has done softer, local stories like these in recent months. But on a Monday morning in early February, the channel's reporters and producers were facing a far more daunting news challenge: the Indian Point nuclear power plant, about 30 miles up the Hudson River in Buchanan, N.Y., had just announced ''an unusual event,'' which it described as a drop in the water levels at the intakes on the river that it uses for cooling. In response, the plant issued an emergency declaration, albeit at its lowest level of warning.

headline: The Moderns
summary: A FEW years ago, Douglas McGrath, the screenwriter and director of "Emma" and "Infamous," was having lunch at Michael's with his friend Paul Blake, a producer of contemporary musicals like "Roman Holiday" and "White Christmas." The two were at one of the tables nestled in that restaurant's brightest corner, in the garden of the Rockefeller Apartments, the swankily modernist, bifurcated building whose two undulating facades erupt north onto 55th Street and south onto 54th Street, right across from the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden. Mr. McGrath's eyes wandered happily up and down the elegant, glassy bays and he said, as he recalled recently: "This is a building that looks like the architect actually cared about it. I've always wanted to live here. I wonder who I'd call?" And Mr. Blake said: "Well, I live here. I know exactly who to call."

headline: Homegrown News
summary: THE notion of a 24-hour cable news channel that trains its cameras exclusively on Westchester County and the surrounding Hudson Valley probably conjures up images of live reports on the cheerleading squad at a New Rochelle high school or news-you-can-use from the latest health forum at a county senior center. But on a Monday morning in early February, the channel's reporters and producers were facing a far more daunting news challenge: the Indian Point nuclear power plant, about 30 miles up the Hudson River in Buchanan, N.Y., had just announced ''an unusual event,'' which it described as a drop in the water levels at the intakes on the river that it uses for cooling. In response, the plant issued an emergency declaration, albeit at its lowest level of warning.

headline: Turn On the Electric Road
summary: LAST summer, New York State took a page from California's playbook, using state policy to jump-start a 21st century automobile industry. Albany started a $10 million program to convert its fleet of 600 hybrid vehicles to plug-in electric vehicles and pledged to spend another $10 million to encourage gas stations to install ethanol pumps. Because companies bidding for New York's conversion business must promise to build their facilities in the state, the plan may help move New York to the vanguard of a small industry with big potential. New York's commitment, combined with Google's recent announcement that its new investment company will focus on commercializing an electric/alcohol vehicle, gives increased momentum to a technological concept that is rapidly winning supporters. In less than three years, a coalition of environmentalists, entrepreneurs and tinkerers has developed a viable strategy to reduce our dependence on oil and relieve pollution in densely populated areas like metropolitan New York.

headline: F.T.C. STEPS IN
summary: After a decade in which grocery stores have consolidated to compete against the likes of Wal-Mart and Costco, the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday moved to block a merger between the biggest players in the natural foods and organic sector: Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets. In explaining the merger, the companies said they needed to combine forces to compete against larger operations like Wal-Mart and Kroger that are offering more and more organic and natural products.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: VIETNAM'S ECONOMIC GROWTH -- In the three decades since Vietnam has gone from communism to a form of capitalism, it has become Asia's second-fastest-growing economy, trailing only China's. And now, in the latest sign of its economic vitality, trade negotiators are preparing to put the finishing touches on an agreement for Vietnam to join the World Trade Organization. [Page A1.] MORE THAN HOME IMPROVEMENT -- Home Depot is displaying a growing willingness to stray from its single-minded focus on home improvement. The company's experiment with everyday products like gas, cigarettes and seasonal decorations exemplifies the belief of the chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, above, that Home Depot can not only survive a downturn in the housing market unscathed, but exploit the situation by plowing money into the chain. [C1.] SCOUTING FOR ONLINE TALENT -- One of Hollywood's top five talent agencies, the United Talent Agency, has created an online unit solely devoted to scouting out up-and-coming creators of Internet content -- particularly video -- and finding work for them in Web-based advertising and entertainment as well as in the older media. [C1.] CONCERNS ON RADIO PLAY -- In the last two weeks, songs from two record labels -- both distributed through Vivendi's Universal Music Group -- got a lift on the charts after a radio chain was paid to play the tunes in an advertising program that New York state officials say is used to trick radio programmers. The ad purchases come five months after Universal settled accusations that it bribed radio programmers with gifts like laptop computers and luxury hotel stays in exchange for airplay. [C1.] A NOD TO PREVENTIVE CARE -- With the number of uninsured Americans reaching a record 46.6 million last year, a handful of hospital systems around the country have done the math and decided that for many patients with chronic diseases, it would be cheaper to provide free preventive care than to absorb the high cost of repeated emergencies. [A1.] WAL-MART'S UPSCALE WOES -- The chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores, H. Lee Scott Jr., said the introduction of upscale products, like silk camisoles and 300-thread-count sheets, has proven ''choppier than it should be'' and the company has ''moved too far too fast'' with fashionable clothing. [C3.] PUBLISHERS THINK GREEN -- Media companies have published numerous articles on greenhouse emissions in recent years. Now, large publishers like Time Inc. and Hearst are starting to think about their own production of emissions that contribute to global warming. Advertising. [C3.] FINANCE CHIEF INDICTED -- Robert C. Trosten, the former finance chief of Refco, once one of the world's largest commodities brokerage firms, was indicted, accused of helping to hide hundreds of millions of losses. [C3.] EUROPE PRESSURES CHINA -- The European Union told China that it could face barriers to its booming exports like clothes, shoes and electronic goods if it did not work toward creating a two-way street for global commerce. [C4.] BELLSOUTH'S PARTING GIFT -- BellSouth, which is preparing to be gobbled up by the telecommunications giant AT&T, left investors a parting gift with news that its third-quarter profit jumped by almost a third, to $1.1 billion. [C6.] UNLIKELY USES FOR RICO -- Some corporations are using the RICO statutes, often associated with mob bosses and corrupt union chiefs, to attack other companies, including many that have headquarters overseas. On Monday, Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications company, became the latest company willing to take that leap when it sued Deutsche Telekom for $7.5 billion in United States District Court in Seattle. [C6.] BP'S PROFIT SHRINKS -- Third-quarter profit at the energy company BP declined 3.6 percent, slumping on lost Alaskan production, higher taxes in Britain and a sharp drop in gasoline prices. [C10.] DISPUTE OVER A COMMA -- A dispute between Rogers Communications of Toronto, Canada's largest cable television provider, and a telephone company in Atlantic Canada, Bell Aliant, turns on a single comma in the 14-page contract, and the resolution is worth 1 million Canadian dollars ($888,000). [C10.] AMAZON PULLS BACK ON SPENDING -- Going into the critical holiday shopping season, Amazon.com, the giant online retailer, said it would slow its investment in new technology in a bid to start reaping the rewards of its continuing growth. It reported that its third-quarter earnings fell by more than a third, even as its sales rose 24 percent. [C1.] MANY FIRSTS FOR NEW CHIEF -- Cynthia Carroll, a longtime executive at the aluminum producer Alcan, is to become the first woman, outsider and non-South African chief executive at Anglo American, the mining giant based in London. [C10.] NEW RULES AT N.Y.S.E. -- The New York Stock Exchange moved to bar Wall Street firms from casting votes on behalf of customers who do not provide voting instructions on corporate proxy matters. [C12.] SLOW DAY ON WALL STREET -- Wall Street wobbled through a listless session and closed mixed as investors awaited the results of this week's Federal Reserve meeting. [C12.] DEATH OF A RECORD STORE -- The liquidation of the retail chain Tower Records will have a severe impact on niche markets like classical music. According to one industry insider's estimate, Tower Records alone accounted for up to 50 percent of sales in the specialty genres. [E1.]

headline: IT'S ON THE HOUSE
summary: Wouldn't an executive earning more than $2 million a year be expected to pay at least part of the rent on his primary residence? At Hertz Global Holdings, not exactly. The car-rental company spent Â£2.4 million ($4.7 million) on a home in London for its top executive in Europe, Michel Taride. Mr. Taride does not have to pay to live there through June 2011, and he also does not have to pay any taxes on that benefit.

headline: Fewer Excuses For Not Doing A PC Backup
summary: If there's one New Year's resolution even more likely to fail than ''I vow to lose weight,'' it's ''I vow to start backing up my computer.'' After all, setting up and remembering to use a backup system is a huge hassle. The odds are good that you don't have an up-to-date backup at this very moment.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths STRAUS, ALICE
summary: STRAUS--Alice. The Association for Macular Diseases, The Macula Foundation and The LuEsther T. Mertz Retinal Research Center of Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital mourn the death of our beloved and esteemed friend and volunteer, Alice Straus. A creative and uniquely talented woman, we will miss her abiding friendship, her wit and her wise counsel. We will cherish her memory with the greatest affection. Our deepest sympathies go to her family. Nikolai Stevenson, President, Association for Macular Diseases, Inc. Lawrence A. Yannuzzi, M.D. President, The Macula Foundation, Inc. Joan R. Daly Administrator, LuEsther T. Mertz Retinal Research Center

headline: A Wiring War Among Giants
summary: THE vast parking lot at Verizon's training center here has been packed the last few months as hundreds of technicians, salespeople and operators gear up in a nearby squat brown building for Verizon's headlong jump into the television business. Inside, Verizon is running classes in two shifts, soon to be three. In groups of eight, technicians once trained to climb poles and work in manholes are learning to be ''cable guys'' who can fiddle with set-top boxes, flat panel screens and remote controls.

headline: Conrad Black On Trial
summary: The criminal fraud trial of Conrad M. Black and three former associates began in Chicago. The jurors scribbled notes as they strained to understand the complex holding structure and business arrangements that existed within Mr. Black's faded newspaper empire, which at one point was the third largest in the world and included The Daily Telegraph in London and The Chicago Sun-Times. Two widely divergent portraits of Mr. Black were presented: to the prosecution, he's a cavalier criminal in a suit; while to the defense, he's a persecuted, betrayed entrepreneur, whose gigantic ego doesn't make him guilty.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BUCKNER, EMIL.
summary: BUCKNER--Emil. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Claudia, his daughters Ellen, Karen and Robin, his son-in-law Kenny, his grandchildren Brad, Kim, Adam, Jess, Matthew and Robyn, and his great-grandchildren Jackson and Abigail. President Attilio Petrocelli Sec'y Roger Blumencranz $(6$)BUCKNER--Emil H. Dearest friend for over 60 years was loved as a brother and close confident and partner in business. Our sympathy knows no bounds and our love and prayers are sent to Claudia, Ellen, Karen, Kenny and Robin and to their children and great-grandchildren and their extended families. Armand and Bea Knopf $(6$)BUCKNER--Emil. You will always be our Uncle Emil. We will miss you. Sandra and Donald, Barbara and David, Jimmy and Bill $(6$)BUCKNER--Emil. It is with deep regret that we note the passing of Emil Buckner. A member of the Board of Directors for many years, we will miss his wise counsel, his unrestrained loyalty and unmatched leadership. This war hero will be remembered not only for his many accomplishments but above all his friendship and a sense of humor that kept us afloat when trouble beckoned. We extend our sympathy to Claudia and his entire family. Jerry Cooper, Chairman G.T.J. Reit Co., Inc. $(6$)BUCKNER--Emil. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Emil Buckner. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Nina Koppelman, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GEER, ROSE W.
summary: GEER--Rose W., 92, March 30, 2007. Loving mother of Margo Geer Walker, Charles Lesher Geer and Rose Geer Thorne. Beloved sister of John G. Winslow. Devoted grandmother of David and Sacha Walker, Tara (Moy), Eliza (Karchmer), Geoa, Garrow and Sarah Geer, William and Emma Thorne. Devoted great-grandmother of Jonah and Noa. Predeceased by husband Garrow T. Geer and sister Penelope W. Baker. Funeral Tuesday, April 10, 11am, St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Church, Fox Hill Rd., Tuxedo Park, NY. Services by Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Inc. Funeral Home, Monroe, NY.

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Business Grants Awarded
summary: The city's Department of Small Business Services said yesterday that it had awarded about one-third of the $1.5 million it can grant this year to companies for training workers. The department granted a combined $466,324 to five employers, including two manufacturers, Felix Storch Inc. in the Bronx and G.T. Machine and Tool Company in Queens, and two health care operations, Montefiore Medical Center and the Community Premier Plus health plan. The fifth recipient, Soundwriters Inc. of Long Island City, plans to hire 18 workers to create closed captions and subtitles for films and television shows. The grants can be used to cover half of the training costs, to a maximum of $300,000. PATRICK McGEEHAN

headline: Natty Camper
summary: Camp-bound kids are choosing sleeping bags and duffels in classic camouflage, with a stylish twist. Quiksilver scrawls its splatter-paint logo across a sleeping bag with an oversize camouflage pattern in camel, chocolate brown and black. Made of nylon with synthetic filler and a flannel lining, it has a matching drawstring carrying bag (far right, $61 at Space Kiddets in New York, 212-420-9878). Paul Frank's rectangular duffel is printed with camouflage cleverly shaped like monkeys; it has a detachable shoulder strap and is large enough to function as a camp trunk (right, $85, also at Space Kiddets). The cool factor of these two pieces has made them early-summer retail sleepers, so get them while they last. As with all things camouflage: now you see 'em, now you don't.

headline: NO REST FOR THE I.R.S.
summary: Marriott International is a huge corporation, and when the Internal Revenue Service came calling, it wasn't for small sums. Federal tax collectors are challenging almost $1 billion in deductions that the company claimed in connection with its stock ownership plan. The plan is part of a larger employee profit-sharing and matching retirement-savings fund Marriott formed in June 2000. The chief executive, J. W. Marriott Jr., participates, as can any of the company's 151,000 full-time employees, a Marriott spokesman said.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MAZUR, JOSEPH G.
summary: MAZUR--Joseph G. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Assoc. Rabbi $(6$)MAZUR--Joseph G., a lifelong resident of White Plains, NY, died on February 6, 2007. He was 88. Born August 7, 1918 in White Plains to the late Mary Selden and Moe Mazur. In 1935 Mr. Mazur graduated from White Plains High School and in 1939 he graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (M.I.T.) with a degree in Electrical Engineering. During WWII he served in the United States Army Signal Corps. He was a Captain and assigned to the Electronic Training Group. After his discharge, he came back to White Plains where he became President of Mazur's Furniture Store, Inc. In the early 1960's, he was elected to the White Plains Common Council, where he served two terms. Mr. Mazur was also Chairman of the White Plains Hospital Board of Directors. Mr. Mazur was predeceased by his wife Blossom who died in 1987, and his brother Lester. He is survived by two sons Robert and Andrew, three grandchildren, Alexandra, Zachary and Matthew Mazur and a greatgrandson Elias Mazur. Services will be held today, February 8, at 11:30 am at The Westchester Reformed Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale. Interment Glenville Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the White Plains Hospital Center.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WENTZ, SIDNEY F.
summary: WENTZ--Sidney F., 75, on Wednesday, July, 18, 2007. Sidney F. Wentz of Hobe Sound, FL, Little Compton, RI, and Florham Park, NJ, passed away at Massachusetts General Hospital after a short illness. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, son Eric, daughters Jennifer Rich and Robin Chisholm, and six grandchildren. Born on March 27, 1932 in Dallas, TX, Sidney grew up in Cleveland, OH, graduated from Princeton University with a B.A. in 1954, served in the Navy from 1954-1957, and graduated from Harvard Law School in 1960. From 1960-1965, Sidney was an attorney at White & Case, NYC, and a corporate attorney for AT&T from 1965-1967. Commencing in 1967, he held several positions with Crum and Forster, an insurance holding company, retiring as Chairman and CEO in 1988. He served as Chairman of the Board of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation from 1989-1999. He also served on the Board of Directors for several companies including Ace Limited Insurance Company and Castle Energy Corporation. In addition, he served as a Trustee for Morristown Memorial Hospital, Drew University, and the Hobe Sound Community Chest. Services will be held Friday, August 3, at 2:00pm, at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, RI. Donations can be made in his name to the Hobe Sound Community Chest, Inc., P.O. Box 511, Hobe Sound, FL, 33475, or to Massachusetts General Hospital, Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Suite 600, Boston, MA, 02114 (please specify Gastrointestinal Cancer Center). To sign the online guestbook please visit www.potter funeralservice.com

headline: Tattoo Police, On Their Way, May Be Too Late
summary: MAJOR mistake to mention one's dearth of tattoos to Louis Rubino, a k a Tattoo Lou, 50 years into his very niche career as the godfather of the body art business on Long Island. Mr. Rubino, 66, gravel-voiced and grumpy beyond his years, has seen his clientele evolve from ''your sailors and bikers'' to your stereotypical suburbanites, soccer moms included. Mother-and-daughter tattoos -- the legal age is 18 in New York State, and piercing for under 18 in Suffolk County requires notarized parental permission -- on a floral or butterfly theme are a new conduit for intergenerational bonding. The oldest first-time client of Tattoo Lou's is a 98-year-old South Shore geezer who caught on to the tattoo trend and decided it wasn't too late, or too dangerous, to live dangerously in inky Technicolor.

headline: Asian and European Stocks Continue Decline
summary: NEW DELHI, Mar. 5 -- Asian stock markets continued to fall today as nervous investors shunned the region despite strong economic signals from some Asian countries. The trend spread to Europe, where stocks also slid in morning trading. But on Wall Street the damage was limited, and share prices climbed after a brief fall in early trading. Nearly every significant stock market index in Asia ended the day lower, and drops were severe in many markets. Japan's Topix and benchmark Nikkei 225 indices fell 3.4 and 3.3 percent. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped 4 percent. Indian stocks traded at one stage at their lowest level in five months. The Bombay stock exchange's Sensitive Index, or Sensex, fell 471.09 points, or 3.7 percent, to 12,415.04. The Vietnamese market was almost alone in posting an advance.

headline: Turn On the Electric Road
summary: LAST summer, New York State took a page from California's playbook, using state policy to jump-start a 21st century automobile industry. Albany started a $10 million program to convert its fleet of 600 hybrid vehicles to plug-in electric vehicles and pledged to spend another $10 million to encourage gas stations to install ethanol pumps. Because companies bidding for New York's conversion business must promise to build their facilities in the state, the plan may help move New York to the vanguard of a small industry with big potential. New York's commitment, combined with Google's recent announcement that its new investment company will focus on commercializing an electric/alcohol vehicle, gives increased momentum to a technological concept that is rapidly winning supporters. In less than three years, a coalition of environmentalists, entrepreneurs and tinkerers has developed a viable strategy to reduce our dependence on oil and relieve pollution in densely populated areas like metropolitan New York.

headline: Skin Deep; And Now, a Facial For the Other End
summary: ''Hey slim,'' a man called out to Rhonda Walker at a party last week, ''you looking really good tonight.'' And why wouldn't she?

headline: These Shoes Are Made for Talking
summary: IT was a cold and foggy afternoon the first time that Ulrike Krotscheck's Nike running shoes spoke to her. Ms. Krotscheck, a graduate student in classics at Stanford University, was jogging through Golden Gate Park in San Francisco, and after about 40 minutes of running, she wanted to see how far she had run.

headline: WON'T YOU STAY AWHILE?
summary: Earthlink, which has not had a permanent chief executive since Garry Betty died of cancer in January at the age of 49, is dangling unusual incentives before five of its top executives. Call them ''please don't leave before the new boss is chosen'' bonuses. Michael C. Lunsford, the interim president and chief executive, will collect $400,000 if he stays until May 1 and an additional $300,000 if he is still with Earthlink on Jan. 1, 2009.

headline: CITI'S OVERHAUL
summary: Under pressure from investors, Citigroup is planning to reshuffle more than 26,000 jobs to try to cut costs and streamline the bank's unwieldy global operations. Citigroup is expected to cut 10,000 to 12,000 jobs this year, according to people briefed on the situation. Some 14,000 additional positions will be lost to normal attrition or be relocated from high-cost areas, including its New York headquarters, to less-expensive locations overseas and in the United States.

headline: Dream Catchers
summary: MATTERS were simpler 100 years ago, when junior colleges were created to prepare deserving students for the final two years of a university. In fact, the very first public junior college, in Joliet, Ill., was set up in a high school, as the equivalent of grades 13 and 14. Community colleges today do far more than offer a ladder to the final years. They train the people who repair your furnace, install your plumbing, take your pulse. They prepare retiring baby boomers for second or third careers, and provide opportunities for a growing number of college-age students turning away from the high cost and competition at universities. And charged with doing the heavy remedial lifting, community colleges are now as much 10th and 11th grade as 13th and 14th.

headline: Art
summary: ART Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

headline: Icahn Appears To Fall Short At Motorola
summary: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday for Motorola's shareholders meeting, with some hope that he would be elected to the board. But by late in the day, as the politics played out, Mr. Icahn conceded that he had lost his proxy fight and had failed to garner enough support from large funds to become a director.

headline: The Neediest Cases; For Girl, 3, Every Move Poses Risk Of Injury
summary: ''I'm O.K.! I'm O.K.,'' Shenay Acheampong, 3, insisted, her little voice slightly croaky from a cold. Shenay was born with osteogenesis imperfecta Type III, a genetic condition commonly called brittle bone disease.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: T-Shirt Maker Shifts Production
summary: Gildan Activewear, one of the largest makers of T-shirts in North America, said it would close five plants in Canada, the United States and Mexico and eliminate 1,830 jobs to move production to lower-cost operations in Central America. The company will shut two textile plants in Montreal, two sewing plants in Mexico and a cutting factory in Bombay, N.Y., it said. Gildan will record a restructuring charge of $21.5 million, or 35 cents a share, in fiscal 2007, which ends in September. Gildan, based in Montreal, is shifting production from older plants in North America to newer factories in Central America. It expects to save $45 million a year starting in fiscal 2008 from lower expenses for production, shipping and duties.

headline: Paying the Fare for Quieter Skies
summary: WHEN affluent suburbanites travel, they can be quite fussy, demanding that airplanes show up and take off like clockwork and that anything less is -- to use a word the fastidious favor -- unacceptable. But when they're lounging in their backyards, they want the skies to be jet-free, or at least noise-free; if jets must be seen, they should not be heard. The problem in hubs like New York is that the two desires are fast becoming irreconcilable. American airlines handled 739 million passengers last year; by 2015 that number is expected to balloon to 1 billion. No one wants an airport sprouting next door, with all the attendant whines, drones and roars, so the Federal Aviation Administration has been trying to squeeze in more flights by rejiggering the way planes use air space in the corridor between Philadelphia and Connecticut.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Mazur, Joseph G.
summary: MAZUR--Joseph G., a lifelong resident of White Plains, NY, died on February 6, 2007. He was 88. Born August 7, 1918 in White Plains to the late Mary Selden and Moe Mazur. In 1935 Mr. Mazur graduated from White Plains High School and in 1939 he graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (M.I.T.) with a degree in Electrical Engineering. During WWII he served in the United States Army Signal Corps. He was a Captain and assigned to the Electronic Training Group. After his discharge, he came back to White Plains where he became President of Mazur's Furniture Store, Inc. In the early 1960's, he was elected to the White Plains Common Council, where he served two terms. Mr. Mazur was also Chairman of the White Plains Hospital Board of Directors. Mr. Mazur was predeceased by his wife Blossom who died in 1987, and his brother Lester. He is survived by two sons Robert and Andrew, three grandchildren, Alexandra, Zachary and Matthew Mazur and a greatgrandson Elias Mazur. Services will be held today, February 8, at 11:30 am at The Westchester Reformed Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale. Interment Glenville Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the White Plains Hospital Center.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BUCKNER, EMIL
summary: BUCKNER--Emil. It is with deep regret that we note the passing of Emil Buckner. A member of the Board of Directors for many years, we will miss his wise counsel, his unrestrained loyalty and unmatched leadership. This war hero will be remembered not only for his many accomplishments but above all his friendship and a sense of humor that kept us afloat when trouble beckoned. We extend our sympathy to Claudia and his entire family. Jerry Cooper, Chairman G.T.J. Reit Co., Inc. BUCKNER--Emil H. Dearest friend for over 60 years was loved as a brother and close confident and partner in business. Our sympathy knows no bounds and our love and prayers are sent to Claudia, Ellen, Karen, Kenny and Robin and to their children and great-grandchildren and their extended families. Armand and Bea Knopf BUCKNER--Emil H., 87, beloved husband of Claudia, brother of Rita Nadel, father of Ellen Manheimer, Karen and Kenny Etra, and Robin Buckner, grandfather of Brad and Kim Fields, Adam and Jessica Etra, Matthew and Robyn Etra, and great-grandfather of Jackson Fields and Abigail Etra. Emil was a World War II veteran, a Captain in the Engineer Corp. serving in North Africa and Italy. He returned to the states to establish US Extrusions, a successful aluminum manufacturing company. Later he served on the Board of Directors of Green Bus Lines. He was a former President of Cold Spring Country Club, and a 30 year member of Fresh Meadow Country Club. He was a life long resident of New York but also lived part time in Boca Raton, Florida. Services Sunday, July 1, 11:30 am, Temple Beth El, Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice. BUCKNER--Emil. My sympathy and prayers are sent to Claudia and family. Emil was my good friend and associate. Scotty Ivanhoe BUCKNER--Emil. It is with a heavy heart that we mourn the passing of beloved friend and relative, Emil. He will truly be missed by so many people who loved and respected him. Blanche & Bernie Etra and family BUCKNER--Emil. You will always be our Uncle Emil. We will miss you. Sandra and Donald, Barbara and David, Jimmy and Bill

headline: National Briefing | Washington: President Googles, But E-Mail Is Out
summary: President Bush has referred to the World Wide Web as the Internets, but that does not mean he does not know how to use it. In an interview with Maria Bartiromo of CNBC, Mr. Bush said he did enjoy using Google Earth, which shows satellite images of selected areas. ''I kind of like to look at the ranch on Google, reminds me of where I want to be sometimes,'' he said. But Mr. Bush is no fan of e-mail. ''I don't e-mail, because of the different record requests that can happen to a president,'' he said. ''I don't want to receive e-mails because there's no telling what somebody's e-mail would show up as a part of some kind of a story, and I wouldn't be able to say, 'Well, I didn't read the e-mail.' 'But I sent it to your address, how can you say you didn't?' So, in other words, I'm very cautious about e-mailing.'' JIM RUTENBERG (NYT)

headline: Short Sales: Saving Borrowers The Stigma of Foreclosure
summary: HOMEOWNERS who have seen the value of their houses drop below the amount left on their mortgages and who are struggling to make their monthly payments often believe their only option is to walk away from the loans and accept a foreclosure. Not so, lenders say. Borrowers can both avoid foreclosure and escape their mortgage debt, provided they are willing to give up their homes and accept at least some collateral damage to their credit ratings.

headline: The Government's Con Ed Bill
summary: SHOULD American taxpayers help Con Ed provide New York City's financial district with a safer power supply? The Department of Homeland Security thinks so. It has decided to pay the electric company as much as $25 million to install a high-tech line between two substations in Lower Manhattan that would be more resilient than the current line in the event of a terrorist attack, severe weather or a simple operating error by the electric company.

headline: Op-Ed; The Government's Con Ed Bill
summary: SHOULD American taxpayers help Con Ed provide New York City's financial district with a safer power supply? The Department of Homeland Security thinks so. It has decided to pay the electric company as much as $25 million to install a high-tech line between two substations in Lower Manhattan that would be more resilient than the current line in the event of a terrorist attack, severe weather or a simple operating error by the electric company.

headline: TiVo's New Tack
summary: TiVo is a company that many adore -- especially those who like an underdog. In 1997 it popularized the digital video recorder, or DVR, which lets you pause live TV and fast-forward through the ads. A decade later, it is floundering in the face of generic copycats and the reluctance of many cable and satellite customers to have a second box. But there was hope for TiVo fans at C.E.S. After nearly a year of development, the company announced that it had finished tailoring its famously user-friendly service for the set-top boxes of the cable giant Comcast -- the fruits of a partnership announced last spring.

headline: Citigroup Finds Taker For Hard Job
summary: Talk about a tough job description: Help wanted. Chief financial officer for one of the world's largest banks. Must be able to reverse a course of underperformance for which the company's chief executive has taken the blame. For Gary L. Crittenden, who was named yesterday as Citigroup's new finance chief, it is ''the best job I could ever imagine.''

headline: The Rush to Vaccinate
summary: THERE'S nothing wrong with drug makers publicizing their products, but the lure of lucrative government contracts can prompt them to play fast and loose. In lobbying state lawmakers to make its latest vaccine mandatory, Merck has greatly exaggerated both the threat of a disease and the ability of a drug to prevent it. (True, Merck has promised to stop lobbying, but lawmakers and the public are still suffering under misconceptions that the drug company has done nothing to correct.) The drug in question is Gardasil, a vaccine for four types of human papillomavirus, or HPV, two of which are responsible for 70 percent of cervical cancer cases. The Food and Drug Administration approved Gardasil last year for use against HPV in females aged 9 to 26.

headline: Steinbrenner Gives Torre Message of Support
summary: The last time the Yankees struggled against a prominent rival, at the end of April, they were losing badly to the Boston Red Sox and the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, was considering whether to fire Manager Joe Torre. Not so this past weekend. Torre spoke with Steinbrenner before Saturday's loss to the Mets, taking the telephone from General Manager Brian Cashman while Cashman was talking to Steinbrenner in Torre's office. Torre was pleased with Steinbrenner's message.

headline: The Rush to Vaccinate
summary: THERE'S nothing wrong with drug makers publicizing their products, but the lure of lucrative government contracts can prompt them to play fast and loose. In lobbying state lawmakers to make its latest vaccine mandatory, Merck has greatly exaggerated both the threat of a disease and the ability of a drug to prevent it. (True, Merck has promised to stop lobbying, but lawmakers and the public are still suffering under misconceptions that the drug company has done nothing to correct.) The drug in question is Gardasil, a vaccine for four types of human papillomavirus, or HPV, two of which are responsible for 70 percent of cervical cancer cases. The Food and Drug Administration approved Gardasil last year for use against HPV in females aged 9 to 26.

headline: Warning Given On Drug's Use To Treat Lupus
summary: Biogen Idec and Genentech have warned doctors of two deaths among patients receiving the cancer drug Rituxan as a treatment for the autoimmune disorder lupus. The medicine, used to treat patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and rheumatoid arthritis, is not approved as a therapy for lupus, Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday in a regulatory filing. The patients developed a rare brain infection called progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, or P.M.L., the companies said.

headline: Don Imus, Over and Out
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Off the Air: The Light Goes Out for Don Imus'' (Business Day, April 13):

headline: Power to the People
summary: CON EDISON has been feeling the heat -- or at least I hope it has. Recent reports by the state's Public Service Commission have faulted the utility for the breakdown of numerous feeder cables during the power failure last summer in Queens and for not preparing and mobilizing quickly enough when powerful windstorms hit Westchester County in July and September. The Westchester cases, in which tens of thousands of customers lost electricity, some for more than three days, were primarily a communications and staffing problem that, while serious, should be easy for officials to resolve. The Queens blackout, which left 174,000 customers without power, some for as long as nine days, is more serious.

headline: A Lovely Parting Gift For Her Ex-Employer
summary: In her first public appearance since her well-publicized firing as Wal-Mart's top advertising executive, Julie Roehm resurfaced at the Reuters Newsmakers panel discussion on Super Bowl advertising in Times Square on Wednesday, and she quickly demonstrated that she had lost none of her ability to deliver pithy, quotable remarks. Asked where she is considering moving now that she no longer works for Wal-Mart, Ms. Roehm replied, smiling, ''In a town that doesn't end in 'ville,' '' a sly reference to the rural home of her former employer, Bentonville, Ark.

headline: You Won't Find It Here
summary: To the Editor: Re ''Wal-Mart Chief Writes Off New York'' (Business Day, March 28):

headline: The Shifting Business of Renting Movies, by the Disc or the Click
summary: Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, lists more than five dozen personalities whose obituaries were published prematurely. Someone may want to add Netflix to that list. The impending death of the company, with its online system for renting DVDs delivered by mail, was predicted late in 2002, when Wal-Mart said it would enter the business; again last year, when Apple and Amazon announced movie-downloading services; and again last week, after the introduction of a series of products and services intended to bring Internet video to television sets.

headline: 'Healthy' Foods? Look Again
summary: To the Editor: Re ''The Package May Say Healthy, but This Grocer Begs to Differ'' (front page, Nov. 6):

headline: Lights Out
summary: ONE evening late last month, Gary Dennis was striding around Movie Place, his video store on 105th Street near Broadway, with a cordless phone clamped to his ear. His graying hair was brushed back, and he spoke, as usual, out of the side of his mouth. ''No, I'm not going to be in this industry anymore,'' he told the caller. ''The industry's dying.'' He waited a beat, then added, ''I'm going to sell drugs to junior high schoolers.'' Movie Place, which occupies a pale yellow room in a second-floor storefront, has 24,000 titles, making it one of New York's best-stocked video stores; the average Blockbuster carries only about 5,000 films. Movie Place's holdings -- sealed in binders, arranged in wooden crates, shelved high on every wall -- include commercial hits but also the very obscure, from a 1984 self-help video starring Mr. T to a biopic of Karen Carpenter acted out with Barbie dolls.

headline: Fuming Over the Cost of Classics on Cable
summary: LORETTA TIERNEY of Milford is fierce about old movies. At 86 years old, long retired from a manager's job at Schick razors, she likes nothing better than to settle into her brown armchair and turn on Turner Classic Movies, where she can watch Cary Grant or Loretta Young fill the screen with matchless style. ''I wouldn't give you two cents for today's programs,'' she says . ''They don't even make sense. Years ago they knew how to tell an interesting story.''

headline: Going, Going, Gone?
summary: To the Sports Editor: Re ''Extra Innings Throws a Curve, and Fans Cry Foul,'' Jan. 26: As a lifelong fan, I am outraged about Major League Baseball's decision to offer the Extra Innings television package exclusively to DirecTV. If this proposed deal goes through, in my mind it will be the equivalent of a strike, and this time I will not come back and support the game.

headline: More Liquor to Go With Faucets and Golf Balls
summary: Most chief executives are interviewed in their palatial offices, their rugs high with pile, their paintings straight from some record-setting Sotheby's sale. But Norman H. Wesley, 57, chairman and chief executive of Fortune Brands, crosses the street in front of his headquarters building here and heads for a smaller building. And there, at the end of small conference room, is a bar and, on top of the bar, sits an assortment of Christmas-wrapped displays showing off many, if not most, of his company's most famous spirits.

headline: A STAR IS BORN
summary: Shoppers browsing at the Barnes & Noble store near Lincoln Center in Manhattan on Monday were in for a treat. Rachel Fuller, the British singer, performed several of her recent recordings. Why at a bookstore? Because the songs were based on the poetry of Melissa Riggio, the 18-year-old daughter of Barnes & Noble's chief executive, Steve Riggio, and his wife, Laura. Melissa has Down syndrome, and her work is being featured in a series of ''storytime'' events, including the one with Ms. Fuller, at Barnes & Noble stores.

headline: STERN OPTIONAL
summary: The ''shock jock'' Howard Stern has been very important to the success of Sirius Satellite Radio. Subscriptions surged after he agreed to bring his raucous show to the service. But now that Mel Karmazin, chief executive of the company, wants to merge with XM Satellite Radio Holdings, he is making it clear to members of Congress that subscribers who object to the talk show do not have to feel as if they are paying Mr. Stern's $100-million-a-year salary.

headline: EMBRACING THE NEW
summary: Joining a small but growing number of corporate chiefs, J. W. Marriott Jr., chairman and chief executive of Marriott International, entered the blogosphere last week with ''Marriott on the Move'' (www.blogs.marriott.com). In his first post, Mr. Marriott, 74, said he was ''not very good with computers,'' though he said he was hooked to his cellphone and, thanks to his grandchildren, to his iPod.

headline: Turning to 'Hard Money' Lenders
summary: IN decades past, borrowers who were turned away from traditional mortgage lenders turned to the private lending market, where wealthy individuals or small companies offered mortgages with much higher interest rates. Now, because of the subprime crisis, banks are again turning away borrowers with poor credit, and industry executives expect these borrowers will again turn to so-called ''hard money'' lenders. This time, though, borrowers will have more legal protection against unscrupulous lenders. ''Lenders aren't as interested now in lending to some individuals because they're going to have a harder time repaying,'' said Hugh Bromma, the chief executive of the Entrust Group Inc., a financial advisory company in Reno, Nev., that helps clients lend money on the private market, among other things. ''Those people will have to go to private lenders, where the standards are significantly different.''

headline: IN WITH THE NEW
summary: When James F. Davis bought New Balance, the athletic shoe company, he paid $100,000 for it. Now, 35 years later, Mr. Davis is stepping down as chief executive of the company, which had $1.55 billion in revenue last year. Mr. Davis, 62, said that it was ''time to introduce younger and more progressive management'' to New Balance, known for offering several widths in its running shoes, and for manufacturing them in the United States, at five sites in Maine and Massachusetts; the company is based in Boston.

headline: Pickup Pix
summary: ''Which way is St. Marks?'' 1. Tommy Hilfiger peacoat, about $300. At Tommy Hilfiger. Theory T-shirt, $190. At Bloomingdale's. Acne Jeans pants, $285. At select Nordstrom stores. Marc by Marc Jacobs skirt, $248. At select Neiman Marcus stores. Paul Smith bag. Dr. Martens boots. 6. Gryphon New York coat, $1,955. At Robin Richman, Chicago. Tse scarf.
